headline: Beware: the most toxic work environment
pros: Resignation in the probation period was quite straightforward.
cons:
Please beware of Inria Bordeaux, I experienced intimidation, threats, gaslighting, manipulation and disrespect from many permanent employees. Mobbing is a very common here and management do not care. This place is a nightmare especially for a foreigner. 

When you leave, the management will try to provoke you to collect dirt to discredit you, so they can cover their path. They will send you a message that your contract has been prolonged, that they want something from you, etc. and then turn it against you to make you look crazy. 

Being at Inria Bordeaux was the most disgusting experience I ever had. Management is either ignorant or evil. No freedom to do experiments and supervisors often bully by overloading postdocs with unnecessary tasks.

headline: Be careful
pros:
I met a lot of a very interesting people . 
Worked on very interesting projects with quite a lot of freedom . 
Flexible working hours.
cons: You have to know that all the discoveries or innovation  belongs to INRIA. In other words your supervisor.  Meaning that your supervisor may decide to do whatever he likes with your unfinished work once you are left. For example, he can use it to publish papers without your name on it (It happened to me an other people I know). So be careful the contract you sign and the people you work with .

headline: Corrupted and toxic workplace environment
pros: There are few good employee and nothing else
cons: Toxic environment, jealous and not collaborative. I have witnessed research engineers and PhD students fired for no reason just because of personal conflict. The administration keep the back of the permanent staff and their dirty actions. They pretend to be democratic, however, this is a fake face, it was indeed horrible experience and there isno freedom to experiment. However, it may depend from one location  to another and from one director to another, but there is no laws. What freaked me out is that they are thieves, yes, the employees themselves are thieves, although they have security, they can still steal each other, of course there are few fraction who still have conscience.

headline: It all depends on the team you'd be joining
pros:
I find the experience of working at Inria varies a lot depending on the team you join. If you're interested in working at Inria, I would advise to take a look at the list of projects the team you'd like to join has worked on. Also do some research on the person who's heading the team. 

Pros: 
+ Combining research and development
+ You might have the chance to work in either English or French (or both)
cons:
+ Salaries can be much lower than if you work in the private sector
+ Some teams are heavily research-oriented, and the projects you'd be working on will probably not be very practical (meaning that whatever skills you pick up might not be very relevant or useful to you if you'd like to land a job in the industry later on).

headline: One of the best places to do PhD
pros: Everyone working at Inria, from researchers to administrative staff, are extremely helpful and nice. Most researchers work on serious research projects, but also respect your personal and social life. You will get more than 40 working days of vacation every year, which helps during stressful periods of PhD. PhD salaries are good enough to live rather comfortably (might not be that way in Paris).
cons: PhD contract are only for 3 years, which might be short for some people.

headline: Pas mal

headline: Working here won't give you a heart disease.
pros:
Great environment with exceptionally smart individuals supporting creative/different thinking.
Very good Work/Life balance (if you can afford a life with that pay).
Social views on employment (meaning that you will be treated as a human beeing). You can take your kid to school every morning without worrying about being late.
Flexible working hours if you meet your objectives.
No extra hours unless you really want too or you've reached "expert level" in research (meaning that you have nothing else to do except working).
cons:
Low wages considering that you can't work here unless you are extremely well educated (PhD level).
Very political.
Most of the people with a permanent position remain until retirement or until they die of loneliness.

headline: Research and Development Engineer
pros: Working in an academic environment with nice and smart researchers and PhD students as well as helpful administration team. Interesting research topics and advanced methods. Easy to collaborate with other important scientific institutes nearby to carry out results.
cons: Not so well-paid if comparing to similar post doctoral positions in the U.S., especially for living in the Paris region where the cost of life is high.

headline: Research Engineer
pros:
- Great freedom in choosing the subjects you want to work on.
- Very stimulating technical discussion with co-workers who are mostly very knowledgeable.
- Good infrastructure and choice of hardware.
cons:
- Some of the researchers (a minority luckily) tend to look down on research engineers even if they have similar qualifications (PhD).
- The freedom everyone has in the choice of the subject they work on may induce slow progression as no strong focus emerges.

headline: Researcher

headline: Intern

pros: team working, good atmosphere, good life balance.

headline: Postdoctoral Researcher
pros: Good working environment. Excellent work/life balance with lots of vacation hours.
cons: Mid to low salaries. Management needs better domain of english to work with foreign researchers. Paperwork for foreign researchers can be a hassle (a problem not of Inria, but of France). At the beginning, I said that a pro was the ease for traveling as part of your research project, but I had to change that now that they created a huge debt for me for the fact that they moved me abroad for a mission and when I had to go back for paperwork, having no domicile in Paris anymore, they first promised that it was OK to cover my living expenses for that small trip but now are asking me to return all the money because it was actually not possible. This, for me, breaks the whole experience.

headline: Postdoc Scientific Research Quality
pros: Casual environment and flexible hours - superb Work/Life balance. Well equipped facilities and helpful technical staff for most problems. As a researcher you have very little administration and can spend most of your time doing research. Summary: an amazing place to do scientific research.
cons: The focus of research at INRIA is inclined towards practical implementation, rather than obtaining theoretical result. Don't expect to publish a lot of scientific articles. In general the postdoctoral position better prepares you to the industry than the academia.

headline: Nice experience as a PhD student

- It's impossible to get a permanent research position if you don't befriend the right people. It's more important than the quality of your work. 
- For some reason lots of people there tend to regard the private sector as the devil.

headline: Excellent level & learning opportunities, moderate salary.
pros: Access to top level engineers and scientists, opportunities to learn, nice atmosphere. In general, it is a nice place to work in, although all this depends on the actual site (several around France) and, above all, the actual team.
cons: The salary is nothing to write home about and, if working as an engineer, promotions make little sense (you usually either stay the same or leave, no in-between).

headline: Best organisation for doing a PhD in France
pros: Fantastic place to be a PhD student. Great work culture, decent pay and benefits
cons: Depends on who you get as your advisor. Very famous people have less time to supervise you. Lots of holidays

headline: PhD in Computer Science
pros:
I consider Inria as one of the best place to work on fundamental science, which is quite rare opportunity nowadays:
- you can easy find a professional in a particular area around you, find him\her, and get a good advice about your problem
- the environment is flexible (almost no strict schedule)
- the salary/work balance is good (of course, you can get more in application-oriented positions - but here I talk about fundamental science)
- secretaries of research groups try always to help you- starting from taxes, accommodation, language problems, finishing with simple advices how to save money or where to get discount for traveling
-researcher are dedicated to science, especially maths, computer science, formal methods. Good training for your brains for the rest of the life
- if you are self-motivated - it's the best place for you- you will find how to use all these opportunities and to become a strong researcher
cons:
I have got an impression that people hate industry here ))) If you like words like : banking, economy, money, well-paid career, investments, GDP - this place is not for you. People will not understand you and will not appreciate your knowledge about "real-money world". So change your vocabulary to : induction, theorems, proofs, rigorous, optimality, complexity ))) - probably this comment is true about the whole France

There is also weak cooperation with industry because of that- I believe. So do not expect that you will meet managers of Google in the hall of Inria that will instantly hire you. Industry does not care about what Inria is doing and vice versa. Money goes directly from French government that even during the crisis supports Inria quite well.

headline: Doing good research in not really nice environment
pros: Best place to do CS research in France. Most teams are very strong. Infrastructure is good. Lots of vacation days (no less than 5 full weeks per year).
cons:
Strong separation between permanent and temporary (interns, PhD students, post-docs) staff.
Postdocs are typically considered as apprentices (kind of senior PhD students) rather than fully-fledged researchers.
Pay is very low: you get on hands ~80% of the salary amount and from this you have to pay the taxes at the end of year (the sum varies, but approx. around one monthly salary). No supplemental vacation money.
People (administrative or research) never ask for your feedback. Just don't care to even consider to improve something. Basically, it is a mix of arrogance and insouciance.
Many of research staff have quite poor English skills (i.e., have troubles with making even a simple talk about their own work).

headline: Quite satisfactory, good work culture and opportunities.
pros: I have been fortunate to get good supervision for my PhD, enough freedom and flexibility encourages good research.
cons: No major complains really, for engineers and researchers salaries are not as competitive as may be at other places such USA.

headline: Good place for research in France
pros: Very rich place, you will meet and work with very smart people, from different backgrounds and different places around the world. You'll find teams working on many fields. Flexibility is great at INRIA.
cons: My opinion it need to be more dynamic.

headline: Very nice international workplace
pros:
- Nice easy going environment
- World Wide international employees
- Various collaboration opportunities and international relations
- A wide range of IT research ongoing projects 
- Opportunity to work with strong people
cons:
- The overhead of managing paper work might be high
- Possibility to encounter complicated administrative procedures for simple things
- Overall a real nice workplace

headline: Research
pros: with high quality research in France
cons: with my passion about speech processing

headline: Post-doc Researcher
pros:
- Good people
- Nice environment
- Good salary for Rennes
- Vacation days
cons: - None, everything is OK

headline: Pleasant but challenging experience as a research engineer and PhD Candidate.
pros:
Very stimulating work environment with highly motivated and capable collegues.
A professional backing that is a great help e.g. travel, administrative affairs, IT, etc.
Little of the bureaucratic overhead endemic to French government establishments.
Many opportunities to work with industry and support for the creation of start-ups by employees.
cons:
Low salary and little career perspectives. This however, is a problem in the entire research community, particularly in France. 
Although most of the time English is sufficient, learning French is necessary in the long run.
INRIA does, of course, provide support for those who whish to learn French.

headline: PhD student   at INRIA
pros: good work environment, good national and international reputation, very good life and work facilities, competitive salary compared to other similar contracts in France.
cons:
-Little intra-team communication. 
-Research output of each team depends on a few individials not on the whole team.
-Not much long-term employment opportunities

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great environment, delicious food, warm people
cons: Not everyone speaks good English.

headline: Internship experience at INRIA Sophia Antipolis
pros: People know english and hence not a problem if you are not french.
cons:
Problem for vegeterians in their cafeteria.
Sophia Antipolis is small town and most of shops will close by 8pm, including public transport.

headline: comfortable working environment
pros: All essential things are taken care by the organisation.
cons: There is no cons as of now

headline: Really a good place to work
pros:
Flexible time, you can almost decide whenever you want to work at home.
Rearly nice.
International environment.
cons: Sometimes you feel that you need a little more motivation

headline: I worked at a great lab in Paris. Everyone was friendly and helpful to me.
pros: The resources are good, the people are very friendly and helpful.   The other people in the lab are very talented and produce a great environment for collaboration.
cons: There were no downsides to the job or place itself.  Being a foreigner in Paris had its own issues regarding bureaucracy and getting all the necessary documents and opening a bank account.

headline: Postdoc at INRIA
pros:
INRIA is a French national research institution in Computer Science. It is highly supported by the French government to pursue excellent research quality. 

- State-of-the-art infrastructures
- A wide range of research topics
- Highly international workforce
cons:
- A relatively low salary (compared to neighboring countries)
- Research budget if quite limited

headline: Salary of aPhD student at Inria
pros:
Inria Sophia Antipolis is a good place for doing a Phd or research in general. Inria helps you for all
bureaucratic issues if you are a foreign worker.
cons: Even if speaking French is not mandatory, I warmly recommend it for a better integration in the area.

headline: PhD Student in Neuroscience and computer science
pros:
Working at INRIA is a very rewarding experience for young researchers.
The INRIA is composed of interdisciplinary teams with a sound technical knowledge in computer science.
cons:
Low salaries and funding opportunities as in every public research organisation in France.
Connection with research and development companies.

headline: For researchers, it is a good place.
pros: It is a good place for researchers. You have enough space and good condition to full fill your idea.
cons: The language is a problem. It is better that you can speak French.

headline: If you don't speak very good French or you are French, you don't exist (In fact it depends on the specific INRIA team)
pros:
* Brilliant crowd around
* Lots of freedom to do stuff
* Lots of available guidance
cons:
* Integration of foreign employees
* In most teams, if you are not French, you just don't exist

headline: Great place to work, low pay.
pros: Smart friendly people to work with.  35 paid days off.  Much freedom to do research.  No micromanagement ever.  Flexible in hours. Tenured position.
cons: Pay is extremely low compared to standard of other countries.  Pay is pretty low compared to industry standard in france.

headline: Working at INRIA
pros: To do a PhD or to work in academic research, INRIA is a good research institute, work environment is very good
cons:
The salary for engineers is not very high. 
Few opportunities to promote within INRIA for engineers as it's research and technology institute.

headline: postdoctoral fellow at INRIA
pros: INRIA is one of the best research labs in France for scientific research in computer science. It attracts some of the best talents in France and internationally renowned experts in the field.
cons: There are no specific cons I can think of, despite maybe the compensation, which is to balance with the quality of research and people.

headline: work at INRIA
pros:
excellence of the scientific context and the working environment.
Great health care and working facilities.
Good environment and flexible planning.
cons:
No carrer plan, lack of managment, lak of acknowlegment.
Unresponsive hierarchy, waste of energy and diffculties to achieve projects.
Bad IT service
